{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3139213,"name":"Angel Emiliano Mora Saucedo ","username":"Angel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-03T20:18:41.942Z","cooked":"

My team has been thinking about making a gate to close our open chasis and have the cone secured inside our frame.My idea works by means of a cylinder that at the moment of actionate it, the gate opens and at the moment of picking up(the cone) the door would be closed, how feasible do you see that? , and could give us your opinion or some idea to reorentate the cone pls, I would appreciate because I can not find ideas from other teams.
By the way an apology if it is poorly structured or written, do not speak English well
It’s my first song and my first year on FIRTS
I hope you can see the pictures and ask for some dubs.

This will be made for polycarbonate.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-02-03T20:33:17.225Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":425645,"topic_slug":"gateway-for-secure-cones-inside-the-frame","display_username":"Angel Emiliano Mora Saucedo ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/6/06e2b0be908b9d5970f553892d2f063b1a6b4f9b.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/gateway-for-secure-cones-inside-the-frame/425645/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3139227,"name":"Andrew H.","username":"ash4fun","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ash4fun/{size}/65155_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-03T21:31:14.587Z","cooked":"

First of all, I don’t think reorienting the cones will generally be worthwhile. A mechanism that does this will necessarily add a lot of complexity, and complexity is usually the enemy of a working, reliable robot. And besides, the cones only need to be oriented if you’re lifting them off the ground.

I’m assuming based on the mechanism you described that you aren’t planning on lifting cones off the ground. If you are, then you don’t really need a gate to keep the cone inside your robot, since you can just pick it up instead.

Assuming that your robot isn’t lifting cones off the ground, you can certainly use a gate like you’ve described to keep the cones in your robot as you drive around. It will take a little bit of design work to figure out the best geometry for powering it with a piston, but Chief Delphi is definitely the best place to look for help with that. However, I do have some advice that might make your mechanism more effective.

  • Consider having your gate pivot vertically, like a garage door closing, or backhoe digging. This has the advantage that it doesn’t extend so far when open, allowing you to get closer to the substations. It’s also more symmetrical, which makes for easier (and therefore better) driving. It would also allow you to set the “closed” position of the gate further forward, right at the edge of your bumpers, to allow you to always grab a gone against a wall. (The STARTING CONFIGURATION would have the gate open, flipped back inside the frame perimeter.)

  • Consider having another mechanism to “kick” the cone forward when the gate is opened. Assuming that you are not lifting the game pieces, you’ll be scoring in the hybrid nodes, which have 5 inch (12 mm) tall dividers. You can’t drive over these, so with the mechanism you described, you’d have to drive up to the node, open the gate, back up, turn around, and push the cone in with your bumper. With a kicking mechanism (such as simply a polycarbonate circle on a piston), you can just drive up to the node, open the gate, and push the cone into place.

I hope this helps at least a bit!
